Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: An Online Clearing House for Trading Resource Use Rights with Environmental and Spatial Constraints
Award.AbstractNarration:
Previous theoretical and simulation studies predict that a tradable groundwater pumping rights system can generate positive societal impacts including both economic and environmental benefits. Completion of the proposed activities under the I-Corps program may help to develop an understanding of how to translate theoretical results and analyses into a viable market system. In particular, improved understanding of customer and stakeholder concerns and needs should ultimately lead to improved risk management systems that increase profits for all market participants.

Conflict over water resource management is increasing, with large amounts of money being spent on litigation, as well as reduced agricultural productivity for farmers that are constrained as a result of regulations. Successful translation of project activities into public use may provide new risk management tools for farmers, reduce the costs of water reallocation, and lead to an increase in agricultural productivity and profits while maintaining or improving environmental conditions and resource sustainability. Successful completion of activities has the potential to increase understanding of how commercially viable market-based resource allocation systems should be designed and implemented.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This I-Corps Teams Program grant evaluated the commercial viability of a tradable permit system for groundwater pumping rights. Our previous research, funded by NSF, suggested that a tradable rights system could generate positive societal impacts in regions with water conflict, including both economic and environmental benefits. Activities during the I-Corps Teams program grant included workshops, webinars, mentoring in entrepreneurship and the customer discovery process, and interviews with agricultural producers, water managers, policy makers, and others.

The project provided entrepreneurial and leadership training and mentoring to one graduate student (the Entrepreneurial Lead), the PI, and the team business mentor. The project resulted in an improved understanding of the information and communication requirements for online tradable permit systems in complex natural resource systems, as well as of the value that such systems can provide potential customers.

At the end of the grant, and based on hypotheses about the technology and value proposition that were tested with potential partners, the team decided that an online tradable rights system was a viable product.  With assistance from the I-Corps Teams program teaching team, a transition plan was developed. The project team is in the process of establishing a start-up company to move the effort forward. It is anticipated that introduction of the trading system will provide a new risk management tool for agricultural producers, reduce the costs of water reallocation, and lead to an increase in agricultural productivity and profits while maintaining or improving resource conditions and sustainability.
